content:
Is there a functor

−1⊙−2 ⁣:Grp×Ab→Ab-_{1}\odot-_{2}\colon\mathsf{Grp}\times\mathsf{Ab}\to\mathsf{Ab}−1​⊙−2​:Grp×Ab→Ab

characterised by a natural bijection

HomAb(G⊙A,B)≅HomGrp(G,HomAb(B,C))\mathbf{Hom}_{\mathsf{Ab}}(G\odot A,B) \cong \mathbf{Hom}_{\mathsf{Grp}}(G,\mathbf{Hom}_{\mathsf{Ab}}(B,C))HomAb​(G⊙A,B)≅HomGrp​(G,HomAb​(B,C))

for GGG a group and AAA and BBB abelian groups, making Ab\mathsf{Ab}Ab into a Grp\mathsf{Grp}Grp-tensored category?

For what it's worth, Ab\mathsf{Ab}Ab does have Grp\mathsf{Grp}Grp-cotensors: G⋔AG\pitchfork AG⋔A is the group consisting of

  • The set HomGrp(G,A)\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathsf{Grp}}(G,A)HomGrp​(G,A);
  • The pointwise product (f,g)↦f∗g(f,g)\mapsto f*g(f,g)↦f∗g with

[f∗g](a)=deff(a)g(a)[f*g](a)\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}f(a)g(a)[f∗g](a)=deff(a)g(a)

  • The unit Δ1A ⁣:G→A\Delta_{1_{A}}\colon G\to AΔ1A​​:G→A given by Δ1A(g)=def1A\Delta_{1_{A}}(g)\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}1_{A}Δ1A​​(g)=def1A​.

This is because for f∗gf*gf∗g to be a group homomorphism we only need AAA to be abelian:

[f∗g](ab)=f(ab)g(ab)=f(a)f(b)g(a)g(b)=f(a)g(a)f(b)g(b)=[f∗g](a)[f∗g](b).\begin{aligned} [f*g](ab) &= f(ab)g(ab)\\ &= f(a)f(b)g(a)g(b)\\ &= f(a)g(a)f(b)g(b)\\ &= [f*g](a)[f*g](b). \end{aligned}[f∗g](ab)​=f(ab)g(ab)=f(a)f(b)g(a)g(b)=f(a)g(a)f(b)g(b)=[f∗g](a)[f∗g](b).​
Yes, it's G⊙A=Gab⊗AG \odot A = G_{\mathrm{ab}} \otimes AG⊙A=Gab​⊗A.

Because HomGrp(G,HomAb(B,C))\mathbf{Hom}_{\mathsf{Grp}}(G,\mathbf{Hom}_{\mathsf{Ab}}(B,C))HomGrp​(G,HomAb​(B,C)) is also HomAb(Gab,HomAb(B,C))\mathbf{Hom}_{\mathsf{Ab}}(G_{\mathrm{ab}},\mathbf{Hom}_{\mathsf{Ab}}(B,C))HomAb​(Gab​,HomAb​(B,C)).
I guess I'm thinking of both sides as sets really, but the abelian group structures are also the same.
Ah, perfect! Thanks, Reid!

If Grp\mathsf{Grp}Grp is tensored over (Ab,⊗)(\mathsf{Ab},\otimes)(Ab,⊗) shouldn't tensoring any group GGG with Z\mathbb{Z}Z give GGG? Z\mathbb{Z}Z is the unit for the tensor product in (Ab,⊗)(\mathsf{Ab},\otimes)(Ab,⊗), and I thought the definition of "tensored over" requires that tensoring with the unit object is the identity functor (up to natural isomorphism).

But Reid seems to be saying G⊙ZG \odot \mathbb{Z}G⊙Z is the abelianization of GGG, not GGG.
It's the other way around: Ab is tensored over Grp.

Another fun fact: This functor ⊙\odot⊙ preserves colimits in each argument, and it's the universal example of a functor Grp×Ab→C\mathsf{Grp}\times\mathsf{Ab}\to CGrp×Ab→C that does so. That means it is the functor witnessing the fact that "a group object in the category of abelian groups is an abelian group".
Okay, whew!

Is the category of p-torsion abelian groups tensored over abelian groups? Can we define a tensor product of an abelian group AAA and a p-torsion abelian group TTT to be Ap⊗TA_p \otimes TAp​⊗T, where ApA_pAp​ is the p-torsion part of AAA?
(Here ⊗\otimes⊗ is the usual tensor product of abelian groups.)
Yes--or you can also define it to be A⊗TA \otimes TA⊗T, which will turn out to be ppp-torsion.

An abelian group AAA is p-torsion if and only if the map Z⊗A→A\mathbb{Z} \otimes A \to AZ⊗A→A sending 1⊗a1 \otimes a1⊗a to aaa descends (necessarily uniquely) to Z/p⊗A\mathbb{Z}/p \otimes AZ/p⊗A. In that case, the resulting action Z/p⊗A→A\mathbb{Z}/p \otimes A \to AZ/p⊗A→A is the inverse of the map A→Z/p⊗AA \to \mathbb{Z}/p \otimes AA→Z/p⊗A sending aaa to [1]⊗a[1] \otimes a[1]⊗a. So, AAA is p-torsion if and only if this latter map is an isomorphism, and then we can canonically identify Z/p⊗A\mathbb{Z}/p \otimes AZ/p⊗A with AAA.
(Also, Z/p⊗A\mathbb{Z}/p \otimes AZ/p⊗A is the p-torsion ApA_pAp​.)
Oh wait!
No, the tensor product should be given by (A/pA)⊗T(A/pA) \otimes T(A/pA)⊗T.
Er now I'm totally confused, sorry.
OK, I unconfused myself.

I guess you can define the symbol "A⊗TA \otimes TA⊗T" to mean whatever you want, but if you want it to satisfy these properties:

  • −⊗T- \otimes T−⊗T preserves colimits.
  • Z/p⊗T=T\mathbb{Z}/p \otimes T = TZ/p⊗T=T (for TTT a ppp-torsion group).

then you can't define it using the formula Ap⊗TA_p \otimes TAp​⊗T, where ApA_pAp​ is the p-torsion part, by which I assume you mean the kernel of multiplication by ppp. Instead, you should use the formula A/pA⊗TA/pA \otimes TA/pA⊗T.

Because let's consider what Z⊗T\mathbb{Z} \otimes TZ⊗T should be. The p-torsion part of Z\mathbb{Z}Z is 0, so the Ap⊗TA_p \otimes TAp​⊗T formula would give 0. But there is a coequalizer Z⇉Z→Z/p\mathbb{Z} \rightrightarrows \mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z}/pZ⇉Z→Z/p (where the maps are ppp and 000), and applying −⊗T- \otimes T−⊗T to this, we would deduce that Z/p⊗T\mathbb{Z}/p \otimes TZ/p⊗T is zero as well.
If you have a reflective subcategory of Ab with additive reflector, the reflector preserves tensors (and weighted colimits more generally). You can use that to figure out what the tensor is.

What's going on is this. Let's write RRR for the ring Z/p\mathbb{Z}/pZ/p. The category of RRR-modules is actually a full subcategory of abelian groups, which I think is equivalent to RRR being a solid ring (m:R⊗R→Rm : R \otimes R \to Rm:R⊗R→R is an isomorphism). So the tensor product of a Z\mathbb{Z}Z-module and an RRR-module is an RRR-module. We can also calculate that tensor product A⊗TA \otimes TA⊗T by replacing AAA by R⊗AR \otimes AR⊗A = the free RRR-module on AAA first, if we like--in this case that's A/pAA/pAA/pA.
Thanks! I wanted to look at this example to get a better feeling for things. But I screwed up and tried ApA_pAp​ instead of A/pAA/pAA/pA as my way of "p-torsion-ifying" the abelian group AAA.

More generally, if CCC is any category and DDD is a reflective subcategory of CCC with a closed monoidal structure, then DDD has this sort of "tensors" over CCC. If LLL is the reflector and c∈Cc\in Cc∈C, d1,d2∈Dd_1,d_2\in Dd1​,d2​∈D, then D(Lc⊗d1,d2)≅D(Lc,[d1,d2])≅C(c,[d1,d2])D(Lc \otimes d_1, d_2) \cong D(Lc, [d_1,d_2]) \cong C(c,[d_1,d_2])D(Lc⊗d1​,d2​)≅D(Lc,[d1​,d2​])≅C(c,[d1​,d2​]).

However, the name "tensor" (or the more modern name "copower") is not really appropriate here, because DDD is not enriched over CCC, and indeed that question doesn't even make sense to ask because CCC may not be a monoidal category. In particular, in the original question, Gp\mathsf{Gp}Gp is not a monoidal category in any relevant way, and so Ab\mathsf{Ab}Ab can't be enriched over it.

However, if CCC is a closed monoidal category and DDD is a reflective subcategory closed under the tensor product and internal-hom, then DDD does become enriched over CCC and this gives its copowers. That's probably what's happening for ppp-torsion abelian groups.

Mike Shulman said:

In particular, in the original question, Gp\mathsf{Gp}Gp is not a monoidal category in any relevant way, and so Ab\mathsf{Ab}Ab can't be enriched over it.

Maybe that's why I slipped and started talking about Grp being tensored over Ab rather than what was being discussed, Ab being tensored over Grp. When I heard "tensored over" and saw some tensor product symbols I assumed folks were talking about Grp being tensored over the monoidal category (Ab,⊗)(\mathsf{Ab}, \otimes)(Ab,⊗). And it seems like it almost is, via

A⊙G:=A⊗Gab, A \odot G := A \otimes G_{\rm{ab}} ,A⊙G:=A⊗Gab​,

except that the unit object doesn't act unitally!

Mike Shulman said:

Gp\mathsf{Gp}Gp is not a monoidal category in any relevant way

Right, of course. But if we consider the graded category (= family of categories) (Cn)n≥0(C_n)_{n \ge 0}(Cn​)n≥0​ with CnC_nCn​ = nnn-fold group objects in Set, then the whole graded category has a "graded monoidal" structure involving functors ⊗n,m:Cn×Cm→Cn+m\otimes_{n,m} : C_n \times C_m \to C_{n+m}⊗n,m​:Cn​×Cm​→Cn+m​, of which the functor ⊙\odot⊙ under discussion is one component--actually many components, the functors ⊗1,m\otimes_{1,m}⊗1,m​ for any m≥2m \ge 2m≥2. So it does make sense to think of ⊙\odot⊙ as a kind of tensor product, insofar as we also consider the components of an action of a graded algebra on a graded module as a kind of multiplication.
Is there some way to fit units, associators, and unitors into the 'graded closed monoidal category' (Sets,Grp,Ab,Ab,…)(\mathsf{Sets},\mathsf{Grp},\mathsf{Ab},\mathsf{Ab},\ldots)(Sets,Grp,Ab,Ab,…)?

On a related issue, the Sets\mathsf{Sets}Sets-tensoring of Grp\mathsf{Grp}Grp leads to a kind of "tensor semiproduct"

◃ ⁣:Grp×Grp→Grp\triangleleft\colon\mathsf{Grp}\times\mathsf{Grp}\to\mathsf{Grp}◃:Grp×Grp→Grp

on Grp\mathsf{Grp}Grp, obtained by precomposing it with the forgetful functor Grp→Sets\mathsf{Grp}\to\mathsf{Sets}Grp→Sets. (So we define

G◃H=∣H∣⊙G≅∐h∈HG\begin{aligned} G\triangleleft H &= |H|\odot G\\ &\cong \coprod_{h\in H}G \end{aligned}G◃H​=∣H∣⊙G≅h∈H∐​G​

) Supposedly "monoids" with respect to ◃\triangleleft◃ should recover near-rings, but it seems again we don't have units, associators, and unitors (at least if we refuse to work with 'lax-monoidal' categories)...

All this is to say that this is a somewhat weird situation: there are these 'almost co/tensors' between Sets\mathsf{Sets}Sets, Grp\mathsf{Grp}Grp, and Ab\mathsf{Ab}Ab, but we can't apply the usual categorical tools for capturing them...

This also only gets worse moving from sets to categories, as now e.g. SymMonCats\mathsf{SymMonCats}SymMonCats is now "co/tensored" over four different categories: Cats\mathsf{Cats}Cats, MonCats\mathsf{MonCats}MonCats, BrMonCats\mathsf{BrMonCats}BrMonCats, and itself. Indeed, Fun⊗(C,D)\mathsf{Fun}^\otimes(\mathcal{C},\mathcal{D})Fun⊗(C,D):

  • Exists if D\mathcal{D}D is a monoidal category;
  • Has a monoidal structure if D\mathcal{D}D is a braided monoidal category;
  • Has a braided monoidal structure (which is also symmetric since "E∞−1=E∞\mathbb{E}_{\infty-1}=\mathbb{E}_{\infty}E∞−1​=E∞​") if D\mathcal{D}D is a symmetric monoidal category.

On this last point, is there also a "tensor"

⊙ ⁣:MonCats×BrMonCats→BrMonCats\odot\colon\mathsf{MonCats}\times\mathsf{BrMonCats}\to\mathsf{BrMonCats}⊙:MonCats×BrMonCats→BrMonCats

of braided monoidal categories by monoidal categories?
